project_name: Hunts Point Interstate Access Improvement - Phase I
project_description_type:
The Hunts Point Peninsula is located in the South Bronx, New York, and is home to the Hunts Point Food Distribution Center, the largest food distribution facility in the nation. The Hunts Point Peninsula is also home to many industrial and commercial properties outside of the food distribution center. There is also a residential area in the northeastern portion of the peninsula. To access the food distribution center, vehicles must exit the interstate highway network and use local streets. The needs for the project are to improve access to and from the Hunts Point Peninsula and the Hunts Point Food Distribution Center/ commercial establishments, to address the existing non-standard geometric features of the Bruckner/Sheridan Interchange to improve operations, and to address infrastructure deficiencies on the Bruckner Expressway viaduct and ramps and truss bridge carrying westbound Bruckner Expressway and Bruckner Boulevard over Amtrak.
The purpose of the project is to provide improved access between the Hunts Point Peninsula and the Sheridan and Bruckner Expressways for automobiles and trucks traveling to and from the commercial businesses located on the peninsula. In addition, the project will address structural and operational deficiencies related to the existing infrastructure within the established project limits.

project_name: Central Park - Modifications to Gatehouse No. 1
project_description_type:
FROM DEP: Central Park Reservoir was once part of the Old Croton water system and served as a drinking water reservoir for New York City. While it is no longer used to store drinking water, the reservoir is still connected to old, unused aqueducts, which are isolated from the drinking water system by a series of valves. The reservoir is also considered a dam because of its dividing wall, which now normally sits below the water level.
DEP’s project for the reservoir serves two purposes. This project will improve the isolation, protection and resiliency of the reservoir’s dam structure by separating it from the old and deteriorated aqueduct structure. This work will also provide additional protection against possible cross connection between the reservoir water body and active City water system infrastructure, improving the resiliency of the water supply for Manhattan.
Also, repairs to the structure's hazardous roof will be made, including internal concrete and exterior stone repair.
